subject: Learning
title: Laptops in Lectures: Help or Harm?
description: A 60-second lesson on Laptops in Lectures: Help or Harm?.

hook.text: Half the lecture hall types on laptops. They look productive. Their test scores say otherwise.

buildup.text: Studies show laptop note-takers perform worse than handwriters on conceptual questions.

discovery.text: Laptops enable verbatim transcription. Handwriting forces summarizing, which drives deeper processing.

twist.text: Even when told to avoid transcription, laptop users can't resist. The tool shapes the behavior.

climax.text: Laptops also distract nearby students. One screen's off-task browsing hurts the people behind it.

punchline.text: The pen is mightier than the keyboardâ€”for learning.

quiz.question: Why do handwritten notes lead to better learning than laptop notes?
options: Handwriting forces summarizing which drives deeper processing
